results.title: Signatures of the Soul
results.brief_description: Counter-cultural icon Peter Fonda takes us on a comprehensive journey through the world of tattooing. From early tribal origins and eastern influences, right through to adoption in the mainstream and gradual acceptance as an art form, tattooing has been elevated to both art and an intense form of self-expression.

results.creator_credit: Educational Media and Ken J. Widdowson
results.brief_description: Deals with nonverbal communication in humans and animals. Shows the many ways by which humans and animals communicate without using words — including facial expressions, body posture, gestures, dress, and sounds.

results.title: Signals : nerves of the army
results.creator_credit: Bruce Christie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: During the war, without communication, the soldiers were sitting ducks. Signalmen, like Bruce Christie, may not have been on the front line, but, as Bruce illustrates, their role was just as crucial to the war.

results.title: Sigmund Freud's Dora (E)
results.creator_credit: Anthony McCall, Claire Pajaczkowska, Andrew Tyndall and Jane Weinstock
results.brief_description: A critique of the representation of women in psychoanalytic discourse is linked, in the form of an ‘essay’, with modes of representation of women’s sexuality in the visual media. Sigmund Freud’s case history of Dora (‘Fragments of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria’ published in 1905) is ‘re-read’ in three sections: an argument over the politics of psychoanalysis; a thematic linking of psychoanalytic discourse/pornographic film/advertising; and questions, in the form of post cards from Dora, posed about the way women look at themselves. Warning: sexually explicit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anthony McCall, Claire Pajaczkowska, Andrew Tyndall and Jane Weinstock

results.title: Sightseeing at home
results.brief_description: The story of television, describing the processes involved from the time the camera records the action to the time it is reproduced on the television screen. An explanation, in simple terms, of the basic principles of television. A telecast is used to demonstrate from the initial recording of the picture by the television camera to the final reproduction of the image on the screen of the television receiver. Explains how light strikes the television plate in the camera, is transformed into electrical impulses, is transmitted through the ether at 4,000,000 impulses per second and finally appears on the screen at the rate of 30 complete pictures per second, thus giving an illusion of movement.

results.title: Sightseeing
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at sightseeing in China. Tourist spots like the 13 Tombs are visited. The video is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. It also includes an interview with a Chinese tourist guide, a look at Chinese script (the city wall) and short dramas in Chinese. Interview questions are repeated and shown in Chinese script, Pin Yin and English.

results.title: Sights of London
results.brief_description: Shows well-known streets, buildings, churches, shopping centres and other parts of London, including the Tower, and the Nelson Column, of general interest to the tourist. One sequence shows the procession to celebrate the silver wedding of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth.

results.title: Sight and sound
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Don Mulholland, Nathan Clavier and Gudrun Parker
results.brief_description: Lessons take on new life and meaning for children through the magic of films, filmstrips and radio. Everybody goes to the movies, and directly or indirectly learns much of the world. If ordinary movies illumine minds, how much more can be done with specially designed films in schools. We see, for example, how through a film, a class of children “jumps a continent” to visit Mexico, how a filmstrip on cutouts stimulates creative activity; how a radio broadcast can make what might have been a drab history period spring into new, imaginative life. Thanks to “sight and sound,” learning becomes an adventure.
